Fe-Ce catalysts were prepared and then sulfated with SO2 in the selective catalytic reduction of NO by NH3. S-CP-Fe-Ce with precipitation method exhibited the highest activity, which is due to large specific surface area, the abundance of oxygen vacancies as well as the formation of Fe-O-Ce structure, thus contributing to the strong redox capacity. Furthermore, sulfates on S-CP-Fe-Ce facilitate the conversion of Lewis acid sites to Brönsted acid sites, and promote the transformation of low-active nitrates to highly active nitrates, which is crucial for enhancing its activity. Besides, NH3 adsorbed over S-CP-Fe-Ce easily undergoes oxidation and dehydrogenation to form -NH2, which further reacts with gaseous NO, causing the superior catalytic performance. Additionally, NO was activated to form highly active monodentate nitrate and cis-N2O2 2-, enabling the rapid reaction with NH3, leading to the outstanding the catalytic activity. The NH3-SCR reaction of S-CP-Fe-Ce simultaneously involves E-R and l-H mechanisms. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Fe-Ce catalysts modified by SO2 were investigated in the selective catalytic reduction reaction. The formation of Fe-O-Ce structure, the excellent redox ability and the abundance of Brönsted acid sites could improve the adsorption of NH3, and promoted the formation of more highly active nitrate species, resulting in the improvement of catalytic activity in the NH3-SCR reaction. Keywords Sulfate Strong redox capacity Acid sites Mechanisms Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction Coal-fired power plants are one of the sources of nitrogen oxides (NO x ), which have the potential to inflict substantial harm on the environment and human health [1]. The current effective means is to utilize selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3 (NH3-SCR). The commercially utilized catalyst was V2O5-WO3(MoO3)/TiO2, which shows the excellent catalytic activity, but its narrow temperature window, biotoxicity and high SO2 oxidation rate are limited its development [2]. Cerium-based catalysts possess the excellent redox properties in the SCR reaction. In order to achieve widespread industrial application of cerium-based catalysts, researchers have utilized the approach of doping cerium-based catalysts with metal oxides to enhance the catalytic activity [3]. Wang et al. prepared Fe x Ce1- x O2-δ catalysts using the surface-catalyzed auxiliary method, and kinetic studies have shown that doping CeO2 with Fe can lower the activation energy by forming the Fe-O-Ce structure, thereby improving the catalytic performance [4]. Chen et al. synthesized Fe0.93Ce0.07O x and the introduction of Ce resulted in the formation of Fe-O-Ce sites, where oxygen vacancies at Fe-O-Ce site are more promoted than those at Fe-O-Fe site, thus increasing the oxidation of NO to NO2 [5]. The synergistic interaction of Fe2O3 and CeO2 is beneficial for enhancing catalytic performance [6]. The choice of preparation method often affects the pore size, specific surface area, crystallinity and distribution of active species of catalyst [7–12]. Guo et al. studied the role of CeO2/Al2O3 prepared by one-step sol-gel, impregnation and precipitation method, respectively. The catalyst prepared by one-step sol-gel method exhibited large specific surface area, highly dispersed nanocrystalline ceria, high ammonia adsorption capacity, strong interaction and excellent redox ability [13]. Ma et al. fabricated FeO x -CeO2 catalysts by microemulsion, sol-gel, co-precipitation, hydrothermal synthesis and solid-phase mixing method. The catalyst prepared by microemulsion method owned the abundant acidic sites, a large specific surface area and the excellent catalytic performance [14]. Hence, the preparation method of catalyst can affect the catalytic performance. In the experimental, the precipitation, sol-gel, hydrothermal and impregnation method were used to prepare Fe-Ce supports, which was then acidified using SO2. To enhance the catalytic performance of Fe-Ce catalyst, an acidic agent was added to increase the acidity of Fe-Ce, thereby improving the catalytic performance. By using SO2 as the sulphuric acid salt source to sulphonate the Fe-Ce catalyst, the gaseous nature of SO2 ensured a more uniform distribution of sulphate, thereby improving the catalytic activity. Liu studied the sulfonation of FeTiOx catalyst with SO2, which increased both Brönsted and Lewis acid, thereby improving the adsorption of NH3 at high temperatures [15]. In addition, sulfonation could lead to the generation of Ce(SO4)2 and Fe2(SO4)3 species, which had a promoting effect on the catalytic reaction [11,16]. This study investigates the physical structures of four catalysts using BET, XRD, Raman techniques and determines their elemental valence states by XPS analysis. Additionally, the surface acidity and redox properties are characterized by H2-TPR and NH3-TPD. Eventually, the reaction mechanism is investigated by in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared spectroscopy. Catalyst preparation Method of preparation of CP-Fe-Ce: First, the beaker was filled with appropriate Ce(NO3)3 and Fe(NO3)3 species in a mass ratio of 7:3. Subsequently, 100 mL of deionized water was poured into the beaker and stirred until dissolved. The pH of the mixture solution was then adjusted to 10 using ammonia as the precipitating agent. The solution was continuously stirred in a water bath at 80 °C for 4 h. Afterwards, the solution was rinsed with deionized water until reaching a neutral pH. The resulting solids were dried in an oven at 105 °C. Finally, the sample underwent a calcination procedure, being calcined at 300 °C for 2 h followed by 550 °C for 3 h The resulting sample was labeled as CP-Fe-Ce. Catalysts for sulfation. An appropriate amount of carrier was injected into the gas containing 0.18 % SO2/N2 and vulcanized for 4 h at 300 °C. The catalysts obtained by vulcanization were labeled S-CP-Fe-Ce, S-SG-Fe-Ce, S-HT-Fe-Ce and S-IM-Fe-Ce, respectively. Characterization of catalyst The pore size and specific surface area of the catalyst were determined using a specific surface area analyzer. The instrument used is from Bjbuilder (BBETC, SSA-6000). X-ray diffraction characterization uses Cu as the radiation source and scans in the range of 10–80° at a scanning speed of 3 s. The test instrument was from the BRUKER D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer in Germany. Raman spectra were collected in a Raman spectrometer using a Si laser beam. Raman spectra were obtained using a 532 nm wavelength laser in the range 100–2000 cm-1. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was performed with a Thermo Fisher Scientific K-Alpha USA X-ray photoelectron spectrometer. The excitation source employed Al Kα rays (hv=1486.68 eV). Peak fitting on the XPS spectrum was performed using Avantage software, and charge correction was performed with the C 1 s binding energy set to 284.8 eV as the energy reference. H2 programmed temperature reduction tests were used PCA-1200 chemical adsorption instrument. The sample was subjected to programmed temperature reduction in a quartz sample tube and detected by a thermal conductivity detector. The sample was treated in N2 gas flow at 400 °C for 40 min. Then cool down to 100 °C, start testing to 900 °C and collect TCD signals, with a heating rate of 10 °C/min in 10 % H2/N2 air flow. In addition, peak area calibration was performed through standard pulse peaks to determine the hydrogen consumption in the experiment. The NH3 temperature programmed desorption test was used a chemical adsorption instrument (BelCata Ⅱ Japan). The sample is subjected to temperature-programmed desorption detected by a thermal conductivity detector. The NH3-TPD experiment pretreated at 400 °C in He gas flow. Then cool down to 100 °C, start the temperature-raising desorption test to 800 °C, and heat at a rate of 10 °C/min in a 5 % NH3/He gas flow. TCD signals from 100 to 800 °C were collected. Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectra (In-situ DRIFTs) tests were conducted using a Nicolet 6700 FTIR spectrometer. The DRIFTS spectra were collected within the wavenumber range of 650–3000 cm-1. Prior to analysis, the samples were pretreated at 300 °C. Subsequently, the samples were allowed to cool down to room temperature and heated to the desired target temperature. Background data was collected at one-minute intervals. In the NH3 adsorption experiment, NH3/N2 was introduced at a temperature of 250 °C. Data were collected every minute at the target temperature for a duration of 30 min. The same procedure was followed for the NO + O2 adsorption, NO + O2 adsorption after pre-adsorption of NH3, NH3 adsorption after pre-adsorption of NO + O2, and NH3 + NO + O2 adsorption. The gas mixtures used were 1 % NH3/N2, 1 % NO/N2, and 5 vol% O2/N2. Evaluation of catalytic activity The catalytic activity was conducted using the NH3-SCR test instrument. The flue gas contained 600 ppm NH3, 600 ppm NO, 5 vol% O2 and N2 as the remaining gas. The space velocity was 60,000 mL·g-1·h-1. A flue gas analyzer was utilized to measure the concentration of NO x . The temperature range of the test varied from 150 °C to 450 °C. The mass of the test sample was 0.2 g. The calculation method of NO x conversion rate and N2 selectivity were as follows: N O x conversion = [ N O x ] in − [ N O x ] out [ N O x ] in × 100 % N 2 selectivity = [ NO ] in + [ N H 3 ] in − [ N O 2 ] out − 2 [ N 2 O ] out [ NO ] in + [ N H 3 ] in × 100 % Activity test result Fig. 1 displayed the activity results. S-CP-Fe-Ce catalyst performed the best catalytic activity reaching 87 % NO x conversion at 250 °C and maintaining 100 % NO x conversion at 300 °C. However, the unsulfured CP-Fe-Ce catalyst achieved a maximum NO x conversion of 85 % at 300 °C. Apparently, the activity of CP-Fe-Ce catalyst after sulfation was effectively improved, which demonstrated Fe-Ce catalyst modified by SO2 could improve the catalytic activity. The order of activity of catalysts was as follows: S-CP-Fe-Ce > S-HT-Fe-Ce > S-IM-Fe-Ce > S-SG-Fe-Ce, which revealed that the preparation method significantly influenced the catalytic activity. BET analysis Fig. 2 illustrated the adsorption and desorption isotherms of the catalysts. The catalysts exhibited typical type IV isotherms, which was belonged to the H4 type of hysteresis loop, indicating the presence of a mesoporous structure [17]. Notably, the hysteresis loop of the SG-CP-Fe-Ce catalyst tended to overlap, which proved that number of micromesopore was disappeared. The pore size distribution curve in Fig. 2b revealed that the S-CP-Fe-Ce catalyst possessed a pore size distribution ranging from 5 to 25 nm. As for the S-SG-Fe-Ce catalyst, smaller pore sizes limited specific surface area, which impeded its advantageous role. Besides, the S-HT-Fe-Ce and S-CP-Fe-Ce catalysts displayed larger pore sizes, resulting in the excellent catalytic activity. Table 1 presented the physical structural parameters of catalysts. The specific surface area of S-CP-Fe-Ce catalyst was 44 cm2/g, which was closely resembled that of the unsulfated CP-Fe-Ce catalyst (45 cm2/g), indicating that sulfation had minimal impact on the specific surface area of CP-Fe-Ce. S-CP-Fe-Ce catalyst retained the specific surface area characteristic of CP-Fe-Ce. However, significant differences in specific surface area were observed, and the order was as follows: S-CP-Fe-Ce > S-HT-Fe-Ce > S-IM-Fe-Ce > S-SG-Fe-Ce, which suggested that the co-precipitation method facilitated the establishment of an advantageous specific surface area. XRD and Raman The physical structure of catalysts was presented in Fig. 3 . The phase structures of the S-CP-Fe-Ce, S-SG-Fe-Ce, S-HT-Fe-Ce and S-IM-Fe-Ce catalysts consisted of CeO2 and Fe2O3, respectively. Fig. 3a clearly showed variations in the crystal structure characteristics of Fe2O3 [18]. The S-CP-Fe-Ce, S-HT-Fe-Ce, S-IM-Fe-Ce and CP-Fe-Ce catalysts presented several characteristic diffraction peaks of hematite Fe2O3, indicating a clear separation between the crystalline phases of Fe2O3 and CeO2. In contrast, S-SG-Fe-Ce showed one characteristic peak of haematite Fe2O3, which was due to the fact that Fe2O3 was mostly embedded in CeO2 or the small grain size of Fe2O3 [19]. Furthermore, all catalysts exhibited characteristic peaks of fluorite-cerium oxide [3]. The degree of crystallinity of the material was directly proportional to the sharpness of the XRD diffraction peak. Comparison of the XRD diffraction peaks at 2θ = 28°, the intensity order was as follows: S-IM-Fe-Ce > S-CP-Fe-Ce > S-HT-Fe-Ce > S-SG-Fe-Ce. The diffraction peak intensity of the S-IM-Fe-Ce catalyst was the highest, indicating the highest crystallinity. In comparison, the diffraction peak of the S-CP-Fe-Ce catalyst was significantly weakened, which was attributed to the fact that Fe2O3 was embedded in CeO2 and the interaction of Fe with Ce, which could form Fe-O-Ce species, resulting in the weakening of diffraction peak. The intensity of the diffraction peak for the S-HT-Fe-Ce catalyst was similar to that of S-CP-Fe-Ce, indicating a comparable level of interaction between Fe and Ce. The cerium oxide diffraction peak intensity of S-SG-Fe-Ce was notably weak and exhibited a broader peak width, which implied that the CeO2 phase was heavily doped with Fe species. Many literatures reported have mentioned that Fe-O-Ce was an active species, which promoted the catalytic reaction and enhanced catalytic performance [4,5]. Fe-O-Ce species were generated by the interaction of Fe and Ce species, causing the superior SCR activity. However, according to the activity results, the S-CP-Fe-Ce catalyst was the most effective in NO x removal. When SO2 was employed to acidify the Fe-Ce support, the sulfate on the S-SG-Fe-Ce catalyst impeded the activity of Fe-O-Ce species, whereas the sulfate on S-CP-Fe-Ce catalyst augmented the catalytic performance. Compared with the SCR activity, it was inferred that reasonably separated doping of the Fe and Ce phases in combination with SO2 acidification could boost the SCR performance on the Fe-Ce catalyst. Therefore, the precipitation method could yield significant activity improvement in Fe-Ce support after optimization via SO2 acidification, which was related to the generation of Fe-O-Ce species. The Raman results were presented in Fig. 3b. The catalysts demonstrated a robust stretching vibration at 460 cm-1, which was consistent with the F2 g mode of cubic fluorite CeO2 [20]. An identified tiny vibrational band at 600 cm-1 and the D band was observed, which was linked to the vibration mode of oxygen defects [21]. The intensity of the D band of the other catalysts was significantly higher than that of CP-Fe-Ce, particularly in the case of S-CP-Fe-Ce catalysts, indicating that sulfation treatment increased the presence of oxygen defects, which could enhance oxygen cycling and oxidation capacity, leading to the improvement of the catalytic performance [22]. Furthermore, there was an obvious vibration band at 1130 cm-1, especially for the S-CP-Fe-Ce catalyst, which was belonged to the sulfate stretching vibration [23], which confirmed the presence of sulfate species on S-CP-Fe-Ce after sulfation. XPS analysis XPS was used to extract orbital information for Ce 3d, O 1 s, Fe 2p and S 2p. The Ce 3d photoelectron spectra were eight peaks, which were classified as Ce3+ and Ce4+, respectively. As shown in Fig. 4 a, two peaks were belonged to Ce3+ and the remaining peaks were assigned to Ce4+ [23–26]. Previous research demonstrated that Ce-based catalysts with high activity often contained a higher proportion of Ce3+ [23,24], which was attributed to the fact that Ce3+ was associated with charge imbalances, unsaturated bonds and oxygen vacancies [25,26]. The Ce3+ ratio was the highest for the S-CP-Fe-Ce catalyst at 21.83 %, followed by 18.43 % for CP-Fe-Ce, 16.78 % for S-HT-Fe-Ce, 16.19 % for S-SG-Fe-Ce and 10.90 % for S-CP-Fe-Ce, respectively. During the sulfation process, SO2 interacted with CeO2 mainly by adsorbing SO2, which underwent electron transfer to finally form sulfate, Ce3+ and oxygen vacancy [27,28]. As a result, the CP-Fe-Ce catalyst could generate more Ce3+, resulting in the excellent catalytic performance over S-CP-Fe-Ce. Fig. 4b showed the photoelectron spectrum of O 1s. The range of 529–530 eV was belonged to lattice oxygen (Oβ), while 531–532 eV was allocated to surface-adsorbed oxygen (Oα) [29]. Surface-adsorbed oxygen was more mobile than lattice oxygen [22], which could facilitate the oxidation of NO to NO2, promoting the occurrence of 'fast SCR' reaction [30]. Table 2 summarized the proportion of Oα. The proportion of Oα/(Oα + Oβ) in the S-CP-Fe-Ce, S-SG-Fe-Ce, S-HT-Fe-Ce, S-IM-Fe-Ce and CP-Fe-Ce was 52.9 %, 36.4 %, 47.1 %, 51.0 % and 26.0 %, respectively. The Oα/(Oα + Oβ) ratio of the S-CP-Fe-Ce catalyst was the largest. Furthermore, the amount of oxygen adsorbed on the surface of CP-Fe-Ce was significantly increased after sulfation, which was due to the adsorption of SO2 in CeO2 and Fe2O3, and led to the generation of sulfate and oxygen vacancy through electron transfer with Ce and Fe, resulting in a significant increase in surface adsorbed oxygen [5]. Besides, the redox properties of metal oxides were closely associated with oxygen vacancies, which could facilitate the generation of surface oxygen vacancies [31]. Thereby, oxygen vacancies were essential for the adsorption and dissociation of oxygen molecules in the oxygen cycle, leading to the formation of highly reactive electrophilic O2, resulting in the superior catalytic activity [24]. Fe 2p3/2 orbits were fitted at 710 and 715 eV [31], and the peaks were divided into Fe2+ and Fe3+ species, respectively. Table 2 summarized the proportion of Fe2+/(Fe2++ Fe3+) in each catalyst: S-HT-Fe-Ce (33.6 %) ˃ S-CP-Fe-Ce (33.2 %) S-SG-Fe-Ce (31.6 %) ˃ S-IM-Fe-Ce (28.3 %) ˃ CP-Fe-Ce (19.7 %). The Fe2+ ratio of S-CP-Fe-Ce and S-HT-Fe-Ce catalysts was higher than that of other catalysts, which might contribute to the outstanding redox ability. Wang et al. synthesized Fe x Ce 1-x O 2-δ catalysts, and found that the easier electron transfer in the cerium structure was due to the interaction between Ce and Fe resulting from the production of Fe-O-Ce species [4]. Chen et al. noted that oxygen vacancies in the short structure of Fe-O-Ce was facilitated by the electron transfer of Ce4+→ Ce3+ and Fe3+→ Fe2+ [5]. Hence, the Fe-O-Ce species were easier to generate over S-CP-Fe-Ce and S-HT-Fe-Ce, and then increased the SCR performance. The S 2p photoelectron spectroscopy revealed a spectral peak at 169 eV (Fig. 4d) and identified as S6+, which suggested that sulfation resulted in the generation of sulfate species. Gu et al. [32] found that the presence of sulfates could promote the conversion of Ce4+ to Ce3+, leading to the formation of more oxygen vacancies and an increase in the proportion of chemisorbed oxygen, which enhanced SCR activity. Hence, the formation of sulfates could increase the number of acid sites to improve the catalytic performance [33]. Redox properties and acidity H2-TPR was used to evaluating the redox capability of catalysts, in Fig. 5 . The CP-Fe-Ce exhibited five primary reduction peaks at 336, 387, 436, 497 and 617 °C, respectively. The reduction peaks at 336 and 387 °C corresponded to the reduction of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4 [18,32,34]. The reduction peak at 436 °C was attributed to Fe3O4 → FeO [35]. The reduction peak at 497 °C was the reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+ [36], while the reduction peak at 617 °C was assigned to FeO → Fe [37,38]. The reduction peak of CP-Fe-Ce was relatively broad, with a starting temperature of 215 °C, indicating adequate reduction performance was adequate. For the sulfurized catalysts, the reduction peaks of S-CP-Fe-Ce (384 °C), S-HT-Fe-Ce (391 °C) and S-IM-Fe-Ce (367 °C) were belonged to the reduction of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4, respectively [34]. The reduction peaks at 433 °C, 425 °C, 443 °C and 432 °C were assigned to the Fe3O4 reduction to FeO species [39]. The peaks at 464 °C, 466 °C and 464 °C were caused by the co-reduction of sulfate and isolated iron oxide [39]. The reduction peaks of 510 °C, 511 °C and 504 °C were assigned to the Ce4+ → Ce3+ [40]. The reduction peaks of 592 °C were caused by FeO → Fe [41,42]. The sulfurized catalyst produced a new peak indicating reduction of sulfate. The low reduction temperature of sulfate was generated after vulcanization, which demonstrated its greater reducing ability. The S-SG-Fe-Ce catalyst lacked a reduction peak at 390 °C, but produced a sharp reduction peak at 466 °C due to co-reduction of sulfate and Fe2O3. The initial temperature of the first reduction peak was compared as shown in Fig. 5. The S-CP-Fe-Ce catalyst exhibited a lower initial temperature than other catalysts, signifying that the S-CP-Fe-Ce catalyst was easier to be reduced. The H2 consumption of each catalyst was calculated and summarized in Fig. 5. The H2 consumption of S-CP-Fe-Ce catalyst (38.8μmol/g) was higher than that of S-SG-Fe-Ce (26.0μmol/g), S-HT-Fe-Ce (35.5μmol/g), S-IM-Fe-Ce (35.5μmol/g) and CP-Fe-Ce (32.1μmol/g) catalyst, which meant that there were more reduced species on S-CP-Fe-Ce catalyst. Therefore, S-CP-Fe-Ce catalyst gained the excellent redox performance, which was able to promote the production of NH2 and NO2 active species, causing the outstanding catalytic activity [43,44]. NH3-TPD was employed to assess the acidity of the catalyst in Fig. 6 a. Based on the location of the NH3 desorption peak, the desorption peak at 100–150 °C and 150–300 °C was classified as the NH3 desorption at the weak acid site the medium-strong acid site, respectively. While the desorption above 300 °C was attributed to the desorption at the strong acid site [17,36]. Furthermore, the desorption of media-strong acid site of S-CP-Fe-Ce increased at 200–300 °C, while the desorption of strong acid site decreased, which revealed that sulfation increased medium-strong acid sites and decreased strong acid sites. Besides, the SCR activity of S-CP-Fe-Ce catalyst was promoted by an increase in medium-strong acid site, suggesting that it might be the main active sites. Additionally, Fig. 6b illustrated the amount of NH3 desorbed during the entire heating process of each catalyst. In contrast to the CP-Fe-Ce catalyst, S-CP-Fe-Ce showed no great advantages in the aomunts of acid sites, but the SCR activity exceeded that of the CP-Fe-Ce catalyst. Furthermore, catalysts modified by SO2 could increase the number of Brönsted acid sites, thereby increasing the activity [16]. Hence, the promotion of sulphate increased the number of Brönsted acid sites on the CP-Fe-Ce catalyst, leading to a significant improvement in the catalytic activity. The results suggested that ammonia on Brönsted acid sites was much more stable than over Lewis acid sites for CP-Fe-Ce-S catalyst. Meanwhile, the Brönsted acid of the catalyst was beneficial to the adsorption and activation of NH3, and subsequent participated in SCR reaction, during which NO was oxidized to NO2 or monodentate nitrate, thereby improving the SCR performance in the temperature range [11,17–19]. In-situ DRIFT adsorption of NH3 and NO The surface adsorption species of the catalyst were determined with in-situ DRIFT after NH3 was injected at 250 °C. Fig. 7 a displayed the infrared spectrum of S-CP-Fe-Ce catalyst. With the introduction of NH3, multiple ammonia species peaks gradually appeared, such as NH4 + adsorbed at Brönsted acid site (1425 and 1696 cm-1) [23,45], NH3 at Lewis acid site (1052 and 1173 cm-1) [46,47] and NH2 species (1358 cm-1) [40]. Additionally, there was a negative peak at 1382 cm-1, which was caused by sulfate species [48]. After the introduction of NH3 gas, S-HT-Fe-Ce and S-IM-Fe-Ce catalysts exhibited an NH3 peak, which was similar to that of the S-CP-Fe-Ce catalyst. However, the S-HT-Fe-Ce and S-IM-Fe-Ce catalysts produced Lewis acid site-coordinated NH3 peak near 1330 cm-1 without the appearance of the NH2 species peak at 1358 cm-1. Additionally, negative peaks at 1620 cm-1 were observed for the S-CP-Fe-Ce, S-HT-Fe-Ce and S-IM-Fe-Ce catalysts, which were attributed to the -OH vibration peak [49]. It was notable that the negative peak was no detected on the S-HT-Fe-Ce and S-IM-Fe-Ce catalysts, but gradually increased and stabilized with continuous input of NH3, which was related to the hydroxyl formed from the oxidation and dehydrogenation of NH3, indicating that the activation for dehydrogenation of NH3 was more favorable on the S-CP-Fe-Ce catalyst. Moreover, both the S-HT-Fe-Ce and S-IM-Fe-Ce catalysts generated a sulfate negative peak near 1371 cm-1. With continuous introduction of NH3, the adsorbed sulfate negative peak gradually was intensified due to the adsorption of ammonia on the sulfate sites, and higher intensity was obtained compared to that of S-CP-Fe-Ce catalyst [50]. Consequently, more NH3 was found to adsorb on the sulfate sites of S-HT-Fe-Ce and S-IM-Fe-Ce compared to S-CP-Fe-Ce. The infrared spectrum of S-SG-Fe-Ce catalyst was shown in Fig. 7b. Upon examining the S-SG-Fe-Ce catalyst, NH3 species vibration peak was not observed after the introduction of NH3. After continuous NH3 gas flow for 3 min, a weak ammonia species peak and a sulfate negative peak were generated on the S-SG-Fe-Ce catalyst. The peak intensity did not increase with the continuous introduction of NH3. Based on the above findings, it could be concluded that the NH3 adsorbed on the Fe-Ce catalyst, which was more prone to oxidation and dehydrogenation to form NH2 species after sulfidation. These NH2 species played a beneficial role in enhancing the selective catalytic reduction reaction rate. For CP-Fe-Ce catalyst, coordinated NH3 peaks at multiple Lewis acid sites were existed by the introduction of NH3. In terms of quantity and intensity, the NH3 peaks at the Lewis acid over CP-Fe-Ce catalyst were superior to the NH4 + peaks of Brönsted acid sites. However, Brönsted acid were formed by the addition of sulfates, leading to a significant increase in the vibrational area of NH4 + peaks, which confirmed the previous suggestion that sulfation improved the activity of CP-Fe-Ce catalysts through increasing the amount of Brönsted acid. Compared with the spectra of the above catalysts, the ammonia species peak of S-CP-Fe-Ce catalyst appeared more rapidly. The surface adsorbed species of the catalyst were determined by in-situ diffuse reflection infrared after NO + O2 was injected into the catalyst at 250 °C. The infrared spectral results of S-CP-Fe-Ce catalyst were shown in Fig. 8 a. After the introduction of NO + O2, the S-CP-Fe-Ce catalyst quickly produced several peaks. These peaks were assigned to monodentate nitrates (1395 cm-1) [51], cis-N2O2 2- (1373 cm-1) [52] and bidentate nitrate (1186, 1042 cm-1) [23,53], respectively. With the continuous inflow of NO + O2, the peak intensity decreased slightly and reached stability after 3 min. The weakening of nitrate peak might be caused by the activation of nitrate species. The S-HT-Fe-Ce catalyst similarly generated two nitrate peaks at 1397 and 1374 cm-1. The intensity and number of nitrate species peaks over the S-HT-Fe-Ce catalyst were much less intense and numerous compared to that of the S-CP-Fe-Ce catalyst. In addition, intense nitrate species peaks were not observed on the S-SG-Fe-Ce and S-IM-Fe-Ce catalysts. The larger area of the vibrational peaks indicated a greater amount of nitrate formation. In particular, the area of the vibrational peaks for single-dentate nitrate and cis-N2O2 2- in the S-CP-Fe-Ce catalyst was significantly larger than those in the S-HT-Fe-Ce, S-SG-Fe-Ce and S-IM-Fe-Ce catalysts, which implied that the S-CP-Fe-Ce catalyst possessed a superior capacity for the adsorption and activation of NO, resulting in the excellent catalytic activity. In addition, the NO + O2 infrared spectrum of CP-Fe-Ce catalyst was determined, and the results were shown in Fig. 8e. After the introduction of NO + O2, several strong nitrate species peaks were generated. After sulfation, a significant portion of nitrate species on the CP-Fe-Ce catalyst vanished and converted into reactive monodentate nitrates and cis-N2O2 2- species [54]. The adsorption of nitrate species was enhanced by the addition of SO2 on CP-Fe-Ce catalysts, which could facilitate the formation of highly reactive monodentate nitrates and cis-N2O2 2-. Mechanism study The catalyst was first exposed to NH3 atmosphere for 30 min, following that NO + O2 was introduced to record the change of infrared spectrum, and the result was shown in Fig. 9 . After NH3 was absorbed for 30 min, ammonia species peaks at Brönsted acid sites and Lewis acid sites were generated. When NO + O2 was introduced, the ammonia peak at the Brönsted acid sites and the Lewis acid sites reacted with NO + O2, and the ammonia species were completely reacted after 1 min. Then NO + O2 adsorbed to form nitrate, and then nitrate species peaks were formed. This result proved that ammonia adsorbed on S-CP-Fe-Ce, S-HT-Fe-Ce and S-IM-Fe-Ce could react with NO in the gaseous state, indicating that the SCR reaction mechanism of catalyst involved Eley-Rideal mechanism. It was noted that as the reaction was proceeded, the negative sulfate peaks gradually diminished, indicating the detachment of NH3 from the sulfate sites as a result of its reaction with NO Concurrently, monodentate nitrates and cis-N2O2 2- species peaks emerged gradually at the position of the negative sulfate peak. This observation suggested an inverse relationship between the intensity of the negative sulfate peak and the strength of the generated nitrate species peak with a decrease in the former corresponding to an increase in the latter. For the S-SG-Fe-Ce catalyst, as gaseous NO + O2 was introduced, and the ammonia peak gradually diminished due to the reaction between the gaseous NO and the adsorbed NH3. Therefore, the reaction mechanism of the S-SG-Fe-Ce catalyst involved the Eley-Rideal pathway. However, after the SCR reaction on the S-SG-Fe-Ce catalyst, the peak corresponding to nitrate species was not observed. It seemed that CP-Fe-Ce was more suitable for SCR reaction after sulfation. In addition, when the adsorbed ammonia species was consumed, the intensity of nitrate vibration peak produced by each catalyst was different. Follow the order of S-CP-Fe-Ce > S-HT-Fe-Ce > S-IM-Fe-Ce > S-SG-Fe-Ce. The adsorption of NO + O2 and the formation of nitrate were inhibited on the remaining catalysts except S-CP-Fe-Ce. The infrared spectra of the CP-Fe-Ce catalyst determination were recorded in Fig. 9e. It could be seen that after the pre-adsorption of NH3, several ammonia species peaks were generated. When NO + O2 gaseous was introduced, the ammonia species peak began to weaken and disappear, and then a strong nitrate species peak gradually emerged, which showed that the ammonia species peak adsorbed on CP-Fe-Ce catalyst reacted with the introduced NO + O2, which followed the Eley-Rideal mechanism. In situ diffuse reflection infrared was used to determine the adsorbed species on the surface of sample. First, NO + O2 was continuously injected for 30 min, and then NH3 was introduced and the changes of infrared spectrum were recorded. Fig. 10 displayed the infrared spectra of each catalyst. Upon continuous introduction of NO + O2 for 30 min, peaks of nitrate species were generated. Following the introduction of NH3, the adsorbed nitrate species reacted with NH3, causing the nitrate peak to gradually weaken and disappear. With the continuous introduction of NH3, the catalyst formed an adsorbed ammonia species. The study found that the nitrate species adsorbed on the S-CP-Fe-Ce, S-HT-Fe-Ce and S-IM-Fe-Ce catalysts could react with NH3, following the l-H mechanism of SCR reaction. After introducing NO + O2 for 30 min, the S-SG-Fe-Ce catalyst only produced a weak nitrate species peak. After the introduction of NH3, which reacted with NH3 and subsequently disappeared. The S-SG-Fe-Ce catalyst produced a weak ammonia species peak after 30 min of continuous NH3 insertion. The findings demonstrated that the SCR reaction of S-SG-Fe-Ce catalyst could react with the Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism. From the peak intensity recorded by the spectrum, the removal of NO by the S-SG-Fe-Ce catalyst through the l-H mechanism was limited. The determination results of CP-Fe-Ce were shown in Fig. 10e. After pre-adsorption of NO + O2, CP-Fe-Ce catalyst produced several nitrate species peaks. But the nitrate species peak did not change when NH3 was injected. With the continuous input of NH3, the nitrate species peak did not disappear. This indicated that part of the nitrate adsorbed on CP-Fe-Ce catalyst could react with NH3. In contrast to the S-CP-Fe-Ce catalysts, sulfation converted the low activity nitrate on the CP-Fe-Ce catalysts to the high activity nitrate species. The surface adsorbed species produced by the catalyst at 250 °C in NH3 + NO + O2 atmosphere were measured. The infrared spectrum of S-CP-Fe-Ce catalyst was plotted in Fig. 11 a. When NH3 + NO + O2 was introduced, the vibration peaks of nitrate species were 1395 and 1368 cm-1, and then reacted with NH3 and gradually weakened. After 1 min, the nitrate peak disappeared and the ammonia species vibration peak was formed. This was consistent with the results of NH3 and NO + O2 adsorption infrared recordings, and the rate of production of nitrate species was faster than that of ammonia species. With the continuous inflow of NH3 + NO, the vibration peak of ammonia species gradually increased and stabilized. The co-existence of ammonia and nitrate species peaks was not observed, which meant that the adsorbed ammonia species reacted with gaseous NO This result showed that Eley-Rideal mechanism was the main reaction in SCR reaction of S-CP-Fe-Ce catalyst. Fig. 11b recorded the infrared spectrum of S-SG-Fe-Ce. When NH3 + NO + O2 was introduced, a nitrate peak was first produced. The adsorbed nitrate reacted with NH3, then weakened and disappeared after 1 min. Immediately, the ammonia species peak occurred and stabilized. This implied that the SCR reaction on the S-SG-Fe-Ce catalyst was dominated by the E-R mechanism, as it was found that ammonia species and nitrate species peaks did not co-exist. The spectrum of S-HT-Fe-Ce catalyst was shown in Fig. 11c. After NH3 + NO + O2 was introduced, nitrate species appeared in 1397 and 1374 cm-1. With the reaction of nitrate and NH3, the nitrate vibration peak gradually weakened and disappeared after 1 min. After that, ammonia vibration peaks at B acid sites and L acid sites appeared, and gradually increased and reached stability with time. The above results indicated that ammonia species was more active than nitrate on S-HT-Fe-Ce catalyst, which was conducive to the SCR reaction of E-R mechanism. For S-IM-Fe-Ce catalyst, with the introduction of NH3 + NO + O2, the nitrate peak appeared at 1376 cm-1. Similarly, the nitrate peak reacted with NH3, and the nitrate peak gradually weakened and disappeared. Subsequently, the ammonia species peak appeared and stabilized. Hence, S-IM-Fe-Ce catalyst could remove NO through l-H mechanism. In addition, the results of the CP-Fe-Ce catalyst were shown in Fig. 11e. The nitrate vibration peak appeared immediately following the introduction of NH3 + NO + O2. With the continuous input of NH3 + NO, the nitrate vibration peak gradually increased and reached stability. However, compared with the infrared results of NO + O2 adsorption, it was found that the nitrate vibration peak was significantly weakened in NH3 + NO + O2 atmosphere. This meant that the adsorbed nitrate reacts with NH3. Therefore, it reflected that l-H mechanism dominates the SCR reaction on CP-Fe-Ce catalyst. Discussion Based on the in-situ DRIFT results, the Fe-Ce catalyst prepared by the precipitation method and then sulfidated (S-CP-Fe-Ce) presented the most suitable for the selective catalytic reduction (SCR) reaction. S-CP-Fe-Ce facilitated the activation of NH3 and NO during NH3/NO+O2 adsorption, enabling it to rapidly participate in the SCR reaction and enhance the catalytic efficiency. In contrast, the S-HT-Fe-Ce and S-IM-Fe-Ce catalysts demonstrated limited ability to activate NH3 and especially NO The S-SG-Fe-Ce catalysts exhibited significant inertness towards the adsorption and activation of NH3/NO. The different preparation methods for Fe-Ce catalysts led to significant variations in their reaction behavior after sulfidation. Specifically, the S-CP-Fe-Ce catalysts retained a large specific surface area favorable for reactant diffusion and maintained the specific crystalline phase structure Fe-O-Ce, which preserved oxygen vacancies and formed sulfates. These sulfates were essential for enhancing the activity of CP-Fe-Ce catalysts. The sulfates promoted the transformation of Lewis acid sites to Brönsted acid sites on CP-Fe-Ce catalysts, which was crucial for the enhancement of catalytic activity. The formation of excessive sulfate might lead to catalyst deactivation, and the competitive adsorption of SO2 and NO was also an important reason. Therefore, the deactivation of SO2 on the catalyst was mainly due to the competition between SO2 and NO, and the formation of sulfate substances might cover the active sites or directly led to the loss of active sites [55]. However, through the analysis of NH3-TPD and ammonia adsorption infrared data, it was found that there were a large number of Brönsted acidic sites on the surface of the catalyst after vulcanization, which were the main active sites in the SCR reaction. Conclusion Four methods were used to prepare the Ce-Fe carrier, which was acidified using SO2. The activity of S-CP-Fe-Ce catalyst was the best, which reaching 87 % NO x conversion at 250 °C and maintaining 100 % NO x conversion at 300 °C; and the N2 selectivity of catalysts was basically above 80 %. S-CP-Fe-Ce maintained Fe-O-Ce active species, oxygen vacancy and active species. Furthermore, the activity of S-CP-Fe-Ce catalyst was promoted by the increased medium-strong acid sites. SO2 acidification could increase the number of Brönsted acid sites, leading to a significant improvement in catalytic activity. The infrared resulted indicate that ammonia adsorbed on S-CP-Fe-Ce could react with NO in the gaseous state, indicating that the SCR reaction mechanism of catalyst involved Eley-Rideal mechanism. And nitrate species adsorbed on the S-CP-Fe-Ce catalysts could react with NH3, following the l-H mechanism of SCR reaction. Therefore, both E-R and l-H mechanisms occurred simultaneously on the S-CP-Fe-Ce catalyst. coredata.dc:description: Fe-Ce catalysts were prepared and then sulfated with SO2 in the selective catalytic reduction of NO by NH3. S-CP-Fe-Ce with precipitation method exhibited the highest activity, which is due to large specific surface area, the abundance of oxygen vacancies as well as the formation of Fe-O-Ce structure, thus contributing to the strong redox capacity. Furthermore, sulfates on S-CP-Fe-Ce facilitate the conversion of Lewis acid sites to Brönsted acid sites, and promote the transformation of low-active nitrates to highly active nitrates, which is crucial for enhancing its activity. Besides, NH3 adsorbed over S-CP-Fe-Ce easily undergoes oxidation and dehydrogenation to form -NH2, which further reacts with gaseous NO, causing the superior catalytic performance. Additionally, NO was activated to form highly active monodentate nitrate and cis-N2O2 2-, enabling the rapid reaction with NH3, leading to the outstanding the catalytic activity. The NH3-SCR reaction of S-CP-Fe-Ce simultaneously involves E-R and l-H mechanisms.
